body.p: Rhinoscleroma is a chronic, slowly progressive, infectious disease of the respiratory tract that is endemic to Central America, Egypt, tropical Africa, Indonesia, Eastern Europe, and India.1 It is caused by a gram-negative aerobic coccobacillus Klebsiella rhiscleromatis, and if left untreated, it can lead to disfiguring nasal deformity and laryngeal stenosis. Increased travel from endemic areas is increasing its incidence in a nonendemic setting, and there is a need for an increased awareness of its clinical presentation, diagnosis, and treatment options among practicing otolaryngologists.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: We obtained approval from the Institutional Review Board at Baylor College of Medicine. We report here 2 cases of nasal and 1 case of laryngeal rhinoscleroma in an urban nonendemic setting at Ben Taub General Hospital in Houston, Texas. Geographically, all patients were originally from endemic areas and presented in the spring of 2010. They were treated medically and/or surgically with an established follow-up of more than 12 months.

sec.title: Case 1
sec.p: A 56-year-old woman from Honduras, otherwise healthy, presented to the ENT clinic in spring 2010 for an evaluation of a right-sided thyroid nodule. A left fleshy nasal mass filling most of the inferior meatus was incidentally found on examination. The patient denied any nasal symptoms, except for decreased nasal flow on the left. A biopsy taken in the clinic was consistent with rhinoscleroma on histopathology, and the patient was started on Bactrim DS twice daily for 6 months with a complete resolution of the lesion. She is currently scheduled for a right thyroid lobectomy with a possible total thyroidectomy for her multinodular goiter.

sec.title: Case 2
sec.p: A 35-year-old man from Mexico, otherwise healthy, presented to the ENT clinic in the spring of 2010 with a 4-month history of right-sided nasal obstruction with intermittent epistaxis. He was previously treated for allergic rhinitis. A large fleshy and friable nasal mass was seen on examination, and a biopsy taken in the clinic was consistent with rhinoscleroma. Computed tomography sinus without contrast showed a 4.3 × 2 × 3-cm right nasal soft-tissue mass without bony erosion. Patient was started on ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily and had an interval improvement in size of the mass after 3 months of treatment (Figure 1). Limited surgical debridement followed by a total of 6 months of antibiotic therapy achieved a complete resolution of the lesion.

caption.p: Fleshy and friable left nasal mass emanating from the septum below the middle turbinate.

sec.title: Case 3
sec.p: A 46-year-old woman from El Salvador with a history of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma and laryngeal papillomas with several debridements in the past presented with a history of worsening hoarseness for several years. Direct laryngoscopy in the operating room revealed multiple polypoid-like lesions in the supraglottis and glottis with biopsy results consistent with rhinoscleroma. The patient was treated with a total of 6 months of antibiotic therapy with sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim and then ciprofloxacin (changed because of right arm dysesthesias) with a complete resolution of all lesions.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although respiratory scleroma is a rare diagnosis in the United States, with increasing travel and an influx of immigrant populations from endemic areas, there is an increase in its incidence in nonendemic areas. Lack of awareness when disease presents in developed countries often leads to delay in diagnosis and can cause nasal deformities, airway obstruction, and symptoms mimicking allergic rhinitis and prolonged sinusitis. The disease process usually involves the nasal cavity and nasopharynx, but it can also infect the larynx, trachea, middle ear, or the orbit.2 The first catarrhal stage of disease progression causes nonspecific rhinitis symptoms that usually evolve into crusting and nasal obstruction with intermittent epistaxis as the disease enters the second granulomatous stage. Extensive scarring and nasal/laryngeal stenosis characterize the third sclerotic stage.3 Histopathology examination confirms the diagnosis with the pathognomonic Mikulitz cells (Figure 2) that represent large foamy macrophages with intracellular rods of Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. Management with long-term antibiotics (3-6 months) with the fewest side effects (Ciprofloxacin, Bactrim) plus or minus surgical debridement is the mainstay of therapy, even though no randomized controlled trials exist to compare various treatment choices and their efficacy.4 Long-term follow-up is vital because of high relapse rates (as high as 41%).5
